segments.text: Mule up in the mountains where there's artillery, mortar fire, and small arms fire.
If a shell hits nearby, a horse will jump over the side of the mountain.
Just anyway.
Because it's startled and scared and out of control.
A mule will actually react like a human being.
It'll go down.
You know, scrunch down.
Another thing about a mule,
After you've delivered your load up on the mountain, you just take the line, tie it up on the pack saddle, slap it on the rear, and it'll go back to where it was fed the night before.
You do that to a horse, he may go towards the enemy line.
Some horses might go back, but most of them, you have to lead them up and lead them back.
Mules are soon found to be the most dependent.
And so, because C-rations can, they're bad enough, but at least they're...
Because we only had three different menus.
They were heavier.
So that's the reason why they got those little cans.
They never got any hot meals.
Not while we were up on the mountain.
When we got down.
Because they had those big, what you call them, marmite cans.
And even one man had a different kind of those things.
But water.
But you're not very hungry anyway.
But I say living like that.
Yeah.
cold and wet, just miserable.
And you were eager to get out of it.
Yeah, of course, France and Germany, you've got houses and basements.
Not only that, but then you're conducting combat or war as you have been trained the way it should be.
Sure, and not up on Devil Amon.
That's right.
And you make a reconnaissance, you plan your artillery, your mortar, your maneuver, and then you go off
And you take prisoners.
You don't suffer so many casualties.
And those that you do, you can immediately evacuate them, even without helicopters.
Now, what was your role in the invasion of southern France?
I was battalion commander then, major in the battalion command.
I got promoted or given a battalion after that Monte Cassino battle up on top of the mountain.
See, once again, I've been fortunate.
I survived.
I get wounded later on in France, but it's a minor wound.
But there weren't many around me that started out when we went into southern France.
That started out when you were in Italy?
Yeah.
Because they'd either been wounded or killed.
And were you in the first assault?
Or would you explain?
In southern France.
Southern France invasion.
Yeah, but that... Salerno, I say it was a fight.
Yeah.
But we got in there.
Once again, fortunate.
We went in in the assault in the beach.
And where we went in, there wasn't any resistance, except, of course, they had barriers all in the water.
But it was a beautiful beach, and it was quiet.
Because the Germans were down lower, protecting an airfield.
So we went in with no artillery preparation or anything like that.
Because the French are living all around.
And it's a good thing we didn't.
So we were able to get in.
And there was no fighting.
The fighting came later on, because the Germans' defensive plan was to counterattack.
Of course, that was their plan.
an invasion of a channel.
They must have had a screen out front, and they would have countered that.
Well, here, they didn't even have a screen where we were.
So where we hit was an unopposed invasion.
Where others hit was a pretty good fire.
But later on, they put an airstrike on us and hit two or three of the boats, including an ammunition boat, where it's at the main.
But we were welcome there in France, at best.
And as soon as you got ashore, what'd you do?
Move inland.
You just moved inland as fast as possible?
Yeah.
Went on, cleared the beach.
Then they unloaded all of our equipment, vehicles, according to the plan.
Then they went ahead and rendezvoused us up.
And then we moved around.
And were any of the French right down on the beach?
No.
We surprised everybody.
People were asleep because it was early in the morning.
We went all around.
We got our vehicles, wheels, all around and got in one of the toughest battles that we had in France or later on in Germany.
And this was written up.
It was up in the Rhone Valley.
Oh, that one.
This was written up by Wick Fowler and two or three others about this.
You see, in addition to us landing in southern France, the 3rd Division landed.

So we were able, and this, once again, was pretty well planned, not by me, but to hire up, where we landed there on this narrow beach, unopposed, went on around and got around and got on the high ground of the Rhone Valley, and the 3rd Division was pushing the Germans.
They had a lot of force in southern France, a lot of tanks.
And so they were having a pretty good battle.
So we tried to block to the north.
Monte Lemire, I think is the name of that place.
And that was my battalion.
We were on the high ground.
The road goes, the main road's here, and then there's another parallel road.
And it's mountains up here, mountains over there.
And we were in a small mountain high in the middle.
In between the two roads, a road on each side, and you were sort of on a hill.
Yeah, so here come the Germans, see.
Down the road?
They're coming all over the place.
They're retreating, but not running, see.
The tank was a whole lot.
Just walking by a strategic retreat?
Yeah.
But one of the problems they had, they could go no faster than that.
They had a lot of horse drones.
artillery equipment.
I guess they put them down in southern France rather than elsewhere because they thought it would be relatively safe and could use them, particularly to put the guns in position.
But they were retreating.
Fortunately, we were dug in on top of them.
We relieved another unit, so they had some holes dug, so that gave us an advantage just to improve the holes that were already there.
And I put my CP in a
Fortunately, not in the house, a real nice house, but in a potato bin that was L-shaped.
So you're going this way and this way.
So even shell fires can't get in this back part here.
So it all started.
And they were attacking.
And knowing that we were in holes, and I wasn't in the potato bin at the time,
I called for artillery down in our own position because the Germans were all over the place.
Just horseback, tanks, trucks, and just, boy, just a nightmare.
Just like one of these Fourth of July type of fireworks, you know, except this was on the ground, right?
That's the only communication I had with our artillery liaison.
So could you get some gunfire support?
Yeah, they did.
So we got our tour, brought it down to our own position.
And, you know, I used to hear horses.
You know, when they'd get hit, we'd hear others turning over.
And I was there at the entrance there trying to watch and see what was going on, trying to keep some kind of control.
Because we had communication with our own people.
At least initially we had telephone and also radio.
We were company commanders.
My exec was down in the low ground where our roadblock was, which didn't last long because the Germans soon knocked that out, overran it.
I mean, they're frantic, man.
So I'm out in front, and I usually tell anybody about my wound.
I had a hero's wound.
That means I got hit in the back during all of this sort.
And I didn't even realize it at the time.
A lieutenant was there.
Were you in the command post at this time?
Well, out in the front.
Oh, okay, out in front.
Trying to direct your soldiers?
Trying to keep some kind of control, seeing what was going on.
So the lieutenant who was there, he was controlling his mortar, our heavy weapons company, the 81mm mortars.
He was there.
And he got hit with a fragment because the Germans...
were then, they were fighting us trying to get them in all this.
And just a small fragment, all at once he keeled over, like we didn't know what happened to him.
We just thought he had fallen over.
And finally, we lifted the artillery and it was all quiet.
All you could hear was some of those horses moaning and groaning and went out.
And we had Germans scattered all over the place.
Well, what, torn all up, torn over?
Horses with their belly, bowels hanging out.
So the unit got a presidential citation for that particular action.
In my room, I say I didn't even know it because I had a pistol belt and then the web belt on my thing.
And he went through in the back, through the pistol belt, through the web belt, and just penetrated.
You were lucky.
Enough to where it was bleeding.
But I didn't even know that until they said, you better go have that looked at because I'm
There's quite a bit of blood coming.
And I went to the aid station over there.
You were really lucky to get that belt on.
Small fragments, you know.
And we had very few casualties.
I really thought, this is going to be so sickening because I know what I've done.
I've killed all of my own people, you know, trying to hold this position here.
But it turned out very few casualties.
And I don't think we had any dead.
They just got down in their foxholes and let the gunfire support do the job?
Yeah.
So basically it was the artillery that won the battle?
Yeah.
That's what I would say, because we were in no position to do anything except to stay put.
And we took a lot of prisoners.
A lot of wounded prisoners.
We had troops on the high ground up, so they were trying to get out of there, I said.
including a general.
In fact, I had his pistol.
I don't have it anymore because I gave it to a youngster when we were stationed up in Washington.
Of course, the Germans got through some of them.
But he was the general in command?
Yeah.
And you captured him?
Yeah.
Was he a one-star general or a two-star?
Two-star general.
I think he's equivalent of our division commander.
I'm kidding.
He was surprised how few troops we had.
Did he speak English?
Yeah.
You can't really tell artillery sometimes which way it's coming when it's hit.
Of course, you can hear the bump over there, but when you're hearing just all this going at the same time, you can't hear the bump in the distance.
It's only by the splash can you tell which direction it's coming from.
Was that about the only major confrontation that you had?
Because the southern invasion went rather quickly.
Well, yeah.
Of course, this is where the
This was the first contact we had in southern France, but this is moving on.
But later on we had a lot more, especially around the Rhine Valley.
And were you at this time under, were you put under the Third Army with that?
No, we were under, when we left Clark's Fifth Army, we were under Seventh Army.
in southern France, and then we were part of the French First Army for a while.
No kidding.
Part of the French First Free Forces?
Yeah.
And who was in charge of that, Leclerc?
I think so.
I never did.
See, I'm only a battalion commander.
Sure, but how'd you get along?
Did you work right in unison with the French troops?
Well, we had French troops on our flank next to us.
How was the cooperation between the free French and the Americans?
Okay, but we didn't find as many French as speak English.
We found Germans and it seemed like they were the average German spoke.
They were just higher ranking.
No, I had a very unfortunate situation working with the French.
Oh, is that?
It was unfortunate for the French.
Well, I'll skip all of the action.
We had a lot of it.
We went into...
Well, I might tell you another one that involves the 442nd Combat Team.
You remember the Japanese-Americans?
Yeah.
In fact, last year we had a reunion.
I didn't attend it.
It was the 442nd with the 36th Division in Dallas.
And they hauled in all sorts of flowers and fruit, you know, for the occasion.
But you know that part of these 442nd people came from these relocation camps.
Absolutely.
And left their mothers and fathers and sisters there.
And then, of course, they came from Hawaii also.
They were attached to the 36th after we had gone up out of the Rhone Valley around three years.
And my battalion was in reserve.
And General Dahlquist, the commanding general, called for me.
He says, I know you've just been out of the line.
It's time for your battalion to rest.
But he said, we've got a problem.
We've got a lost battalion.
A battalion of 141st had advanced and got cut off.
And he says, I want you to take your battalion
been attacked to get to them so we can get them out of there.
So of course I said, yes sir, and I went to get the battalion alerted and moving.
And fortunately for me, this is another one of these lucky breaks, fate or whatever.
By the time I got back to the battalion, of course they alerted them, they were all getting ready to move out.
I get a telephone call that says, just disregard the orders.
We've decided it's too big a job for battalions.
It's going to take at least a regiment.
So we're going to use a full 42nd combat team, which they did.
And they fought for several days.
They took tremendous casualties.
And they got to them and got them out at a very high price.
My battalion would never have been able to do what I've done.
got decimated and still had to have somebody to help him.
Did you meet any of these Japanese American troops?
I did then.
I don't remember now.
I don't remember, for example, what's his name?
How'd they impress you?
The one who's got the arm of, you know, a member of Congress.
Oh, for me.
Super.
Of course, they had a
Not only they, just like all Japanese, tremendous fighters and courageous, but they had a point to prove.
That they were just as patriotic, or better, more patriotic and better fighters than the non-Japanese.
Never complained.
But that was terrible that they hadn't had such a licking because, see, you didn't have replacements.
You know, when they took ahead a casualty list, they didn't readily have replacements.
It takes a long time.
So they used up their capability, their present capability, in just a few days.
But while they're getting ready to preach, I haven't performed with them.
We're still part of the 1st Preach Army, the 36th.
We went to...
into the Rhone Valley, just below Strasbourg.
And the Germans had counterattacked it earlier, and they had a riverhead north and one south of Strasbourg.
So the mission of my battalion was to eliminate that element of Germans south of Strasbourg.
And then we'd been fighting longer than any other day.
I think we'd been in contact with enemy a hundred and something days, ever since southern France.
And we were still in good shape, though, because they hadn't had cagers, fortunately, since the 442nd took our cagers.
So they said, well, we don't have any tanks.
They said, we'll attach
a platoon of French tanks.
So here they came around just before we attacked them.
They didn't speak English.
Nobody spoke French until I thought, gee, my striker or aide, he's from Louisiana, he speaks French.
Well, he spoke Cajun French, you know.
So he came up and
He says they understood him, but I'm not sure they did.
So we planned an attack, see.
We were going to attack with two companies here.
And I was going to send another company around here.
And I told those tanks, do not, the commander there, do not go into this village until my infantry is there so they can go with you, support you.
And Geetri, that's his name.
This is probably his son who pitches for them, a grandson who pitches for the New York Yankees.
Same, of course, Geetri's like Smith.
So Geetri, I said, are you sure they understand that?
He said, well, I'll repeat it.
And he went through the same thing.
Give this company time to get there before you go into the village.
They all understood it.
So, okay, we had it all set at the time, and we got ready to go.
Had an artillery preparation, and attacked.
What did those French tanks do?
They went right around there by themselves and went right on into the village, and all four of them got knocked out with bazookas, Germans.
The Germans called them Panzerfaust, not bazookas.
All four tanks.
Why do you think they did that?
They didn't understand, I guess.
Or maybe they thought they could take the village by themselves, but we knew the Germans then, because those Panzerfausts, boy, they had deadly.
You know, you got somebody in an upstair window, you point that thing down there, anywhere on top of a tank, vulnerable, especially over the engine.
Then we got in the village, and we didn't take the village.
What village was that?
Do you remember?
I don't remember.
I had to look at the map.
I thought about this.
Then I got orders about 10 o'clock at night.
Since we hadn't cleared the village by that time, pull out, because we were going out of the line.
We really didn't go out of the line.
We went to a less active position.
They were going to give you a little bit of rest and put a new division up there.
Yeah.
Third division this time was going to replace us there.
They had a little easier time.
So the situation was like fighting with a tiger, you know, and they say, let that tiger eat you.
I said, how am I going to get out of this village?
It's night.
I've got one platoon that's surrounded, almost surrounded.
I'm going to have a heck of a time disengaging because the Germans don't want to disengage.
We got into their village, and they want to get revenge and get us out.
Well, I said, do the best you can, but be sure you're out by 12 o'clock.
So we had to leave those French tank.
I think they got most of the wounded out of there.
And that platoon that was almost cut off was able to,
to get out and cover darkness.
Now, you learn a lot of things in wartime, but I learned a lesson in the Strasburg.
We were to occupy an island.
If you've ever been to Strasburg, there's an island in the Rhine.
And Strasburg is a port.
And there's a whole row of warehouses for the river traffic, commercial traffic.
And our mission was to occupy, defend.
Strasburg, too, was an open city in itself.
Now, the island all around each side, that wasn't considered open.
So we moved in, and it was quiet.
And we stayed there.
And what I noticed as we went in there, there was a tower to the entrance to the harbor.
And the big tower clock had been shut out.
And the warehouses, of course you're taking a look at it, had been looted, at least broken into.
Most of the valuable cargo had been taken.
But everything was fine.
And so the Burgermeister had been down to see me.
I said, how's everything?
He said, everything's fine.
Yes, it's quiet.
His troops have been very orderly.
No problem.
And we were ordered out.
And I don't remember who replaced us.
And we were on up, engaged again heavily along the Rhine River.
This time we were providing the infantry troops for armor division.
And the Inspector General
came up, and there I was, you know, tired and sweating out all of this and trying to conduct the operation.
He said, I hate to bother you, but I've got a very important subject to discuss with you.
I said, yeah.
He said, yes, have you got $2 million?
I said, no, I haven't got 15 cents.
What are you getting at?

He said, well, for your information, the Burgermeister of Sprossburg has submitted a claim against the American U.S. Army for $2 million for knocking out that clock and all that cargo that was in the warehouse that was stolen.
I said, well, you're talking to the wrong person.
Because it was out when we got there, both the clock and the cargo.
He said, well, it couldn't have been.
I said, well, why couldn't it have been?
Maybe the 3rd Division got it.
He said, no.
The 3rd Division had the clean bill of health.
When they left, they had the burglar master to sign that everything is just as they found it and nothing has been destroyed.
And he said, don't worry about it because I'm sure that we can work this out.
I know that you're telling the truth, but if I have this paperwork, I've got to run down.
What had happened is
The French, the first French army, they had liberated Strasbourg.
They shot out the clock, and they hauled off, because they had a lot of chalk candy and things like that, you know, to wear out that car.
They hauled all of that on.
But the French didn't want to, you know, say the French did it.
and I guess they figured that Uncle Sugar was coming along, and we might have paid for it.
I never heard of it since.
But that's what could happen.
I mean, when you went into a German town and occupied it, you would have to sign chits saying that you had, you know, and have the Burgermeister sign them saying that you had not stolen any property.
That's the only time I ever heard of that, but Strasburg is a situation that,
What's different?
There have been very, and I'm sure that the 3rd Division was smart enough to know that.
You know, it's an open city, and if the Germans haven't tore things up, and we certainly don't want to be accused of sometimes soldiers, you know.
Oh, yeah.
They call it liberating.
They go out and go into a house or store or a building and get a canvas or something else.
So they had a clean bill of health signed with the Bergen-Meister.
And I guess you can't blame him for not trying to get reimbursement for things, even in the middle of the war.
Was this during the time of the Battle of the Bulge?
No.
We're still in France.
I was in Germany during the Battle of the Bulge.
We haven't crossed the Rhine yet.
Okay, so this is before...
December of 1944.
When is this?
I don't know.
I should have gotten... Well, I don't have my journals.
That's right.
I'll loan my journals to a guy who's writing a book.
I have mostly journals.
Who's journals?
I can get his name.
You've got that machine over there.
Vincent M. Lockhart.
And he's writing a book, A History of the 36th Division?
In France and Germany.
And was he in the division?
Yeah.
He was in the headquarters, but he was with the division almost the entire time.
I left Texas with him and
I came home on the day.
Except for being in.
OK.
So rental.
R&R I didn't miss a day with the 36 today.
Not one day.
except going on that trip on and off.
My goodness.
Okay, so this is right before the Battle of the Bulge.
What was the situation?
Were you involved with that battle in December of 1940?
Oh, in the Bulge.
Or was that too far north of you?
Oh, yes, north of it.
Yeah.
Was it too far north?
Yeah.
Because we went
We went into Germany at Wissenberg.
And that was through the secret line.
And that, too, was another example where rather than decimate your troops on the frontal attack in the lowland, my battalion was sent
through the mountain, where we still had a pretty strong defense, but not like it was down where it was designed, you know, for anti-tank guns.
And we were able to get through the sacred line without very many casualties.
But we lost a tank going through and in the village, five pounds or thousands on the second story, you know, and fired it down on them.
It was terrible because they,
It was a lieutenant in the tank, had the turret open with his head out.
It was a night, see, so, and it was quiet.
I see the panther's out there.
So he shot that thing down there and tore his head, practically, off.
Of course, he killed and missed him.
And knocked out the tank, and it went on down there and set it to fire.
Did it kill everybody in the tank?
I don't recall.
I haven't thought about these things in years.
I can remember the incident, and I can see that gory mass of splattered brain and just the stem of his neck sticking out.
And they got his body out before the tank really got to burn.
And it was able to push the tank, too, out of the street.
It was a narrow street, so the rest of the column got burned.
But we left it burning.
So how many of the others were killed or got out?
I don't know.
Most of the tanks, you know, have an escape hatch at the bottom that you can get in or out.
Now, what was the condition of the Siegfried line when you approached it?
Was it heavily damaged or was it...
in pretty good shape.
We put down a terrific artillery barrage on that thing.
And the mountains.
Now, they had bunkers and they were manned and with crossfire.
But nothing like down in the Rhine plain.
Boy, that was... Not only had bunkers, but they had big tank ditches, you know.
Mine and barbed wire.
And, uh,
They were designed that neither man nor machine could get through those things.
Up in the mountains, they had the bunkers.
They had protective wire around the bunkers where you couldn't get close enough to lob hand grenades under the portal.
But this just shows you how to protect the bunker.
They had
defensive foxholes around the bunker outside.
So I imagine psychologically, they just didn't feel like being sitting in there and waiting for somebody with a flamethrower or something to stick it through them.
And that was the reason why we had low casualties going through that, because that artillery.
There weren't many Germans left.
For some reason, either ordered to leave or something.
They weren't there.
There were some just for snipers who took prisoners.
Maybe they want to be taken care of.
But we were prepared for a really tough fight getting through that city.
Once again, luck comes to you without having to do anything.
Then we went on to the Rhine River for the crossing.
And we were getting ready to make a river crossing at this
ferry landing.
It was the bridge that was the ferry.
And so often in Germany there's a tavern on one side of the river.
This is on our side of the river.
And it was there just before daylight.
It was cold, damp, and we were all moving around, getting all set.
About that time,
in that cavern.
Let go of it.
You know one of these Germans where they played the umpah and got drums, you know, the whole thing, a player, piano type of thing.
That thing started running.
We got somebody to find out what the hell that is.
Some G.I.
had been in there and somehow he had tripped that thing where, you know, like any G.I.
looking around, what is this thing?
He got it started playing.
But the Germans didn't resist across the Rhine there.
No kidding?
They must have been concentrated up north, huh?
Yeah.
And this was a... You could have been slaughtered.
This is a... And we got across there, and of course, they had a big fight up in Remagen Bridgehead.
That was a great... Of course, that was up in industrial parts down there.
Yeah.
In fact, we claimed, Seventh Army claimed, we were the first one to cross the Rhine.
And I think the same on the Remagen.
And when you got... See, when you're down on one end and you're fighting like we're still in there, you really don't know what the hell's going on.
I wasn't aware of any of the Battle of the Bulge until later on.
We felt the effects because they picked up several Germans in American uniforms.
Oh, really?
Yeah.
And they called them with a password.
You know, they'd figure out everything, like the Germans being smart.
But they can't master baseball, for example.
You know, you start asking her about pictures and who did this.
different things like that.
So these guys were sabotaged, you were going to sabotage them?
Yeah, I was part of a whole system of those.
We didn't know at the time, all at once, we got the word to be very suspicious of anybody going there.
Germans dressed in American uniforms, driving jeeps.
My battalion didn't capture any of them, but the regiment did.
Captured two jeep loads full of these men.
No kidding.
They were the most GI-looking characters you've ever seen.
They later admitted that they were German.
They wouldn't tell what their mission was if they were German.
They may have got more information if they evacuated.
And then you continued your drive into Germany.
Yeah.
And we went across the Rhine at another place.
And this was down
near Mannheim.
And you know who was directing traffic there at that crossing?
It was a ponton bridge, General Patton.
No kidding.
He was out there directing traffic, because he was trying to get the infantry unit across, because he had an armor division that was coming.
He wanted to get them all cleared out.
Of course, he was dissatisfied with what the MPs were doing,
I had the first experience I had with General Patton, the only experience, except this, and I was just passing by, was in the Louisiana Maneuvers.
Oh, yeah, he was down there.
Yeah, he was testing.
Yeah, he was testing his...
Well, it was the early 40s.
Was it 1940?
He commanded the armored unit at Fort Bennett.

And he, of course, being a scholar all of his life on the professional warrants and military leaders and tactics and strategies, he knew about the German blitzkrieg tactics of using panzers and infantry, fast-moving infantry.
In the past, you know, they had tank units and they had infantry units, and they both fought their own kind of war.
Of course, in World War II, they just had a very primitive tank.
And not many of them were not very successful.
World War I. Yeah, World War I.
So he's going to test this out during this maneuver.
So the 143rd Infantry.
of the Texas National Guard was attached to his unit for this particular operation.
And so I reported to his headquarters as liaison officer.
And of course, you know liaison officer, you're not one of the other liaison officers.
Your job is to keep abreast of the situation as much as you can in that headquarters without being truces to get in the way
being noticed too much.
So you kind of slip around and look and listen.
And your main job, of course, is to know where your unit is at all times.
Because that's the purpose of you being there.
So you expedite.
Those days we didn't have much communication.
Nothing like now with the radio and also
telephone wire.
And Patton was in the headquarters?
He was there.
Patton has a real high voice.
You'd like for him to be like old George Scott, you know, and Patton, with that growling speech he made, you know, up on the platform.
But he had kind of a high-pitched voice like that.
And when he got excited, it would go really high.
Vulgar curse word, boy, he just spewed them out all three and four and every sentence.
So obviously, people didn't get around General Patton unless he called them.
I mean, he didn't want to get his iron.
Then I remember that an officer came in.
He had sent for him.
And he was just raving.
Gosh, he was chewing the poor guy up.
And what he had done, or not done, he failed to meet the rendezvous with a tank truck that was going to refuel his tank.
Of course, that's a cardinal sin because the tank's not worth it.
It can't move.
Circumstances doesn't make any difference.
General Patton was saying it didn't occur.
It didn't happen.
As far as I'm concerned, you're the commander.
You're at fault because you didn't make it happen.
You should have been there.
You should have been supervised.
Train your people differently.
Then after all of that, he turned.
to the other people he's talking to, and you'd think that he was conducting a Sunday school class.
Just like that, he came from a grower maniac type of innovation.
And what did he say to these other people when he turned?
I don't know.
They were talking about whatever they were talking before that guy got there, something about what they were going to do.
I heard him yell, where's that liaison officer from the 143rd Infantry?
Boy, I went over there and saluted him.
Lieutenant Andrews reported, sir.
He says, do you know where your unit is?
Of course, if I didn't know, I wouldn't have told him.
Yes, sir.
All right, he says, I want you to go get that regiment, and I want you to have the lead column at this road junction.
And he gave me the hour.
I don't remember what it was.
Can you get them there?
And I said, yes, sir.
Well, get going then.
So off I went.
And I knew generally where they were if they still lay.
And I found them, gave the commanding officer the message of what they were supposed to do.
And off we went.
We got to the road junction, but by the time we got there, he had already gone in his column.
And he's been criticized for this because he was a very wealthy man.
Sometimes he didn't even cash his paycheck or anything.
So he took that tank column through East Texas, off limits, really.
You know, the river.
I guess that's the Sabine River, isn't it, or whatever it is.
So as a result, and how did he do it?
He used his own personal funds to purchase gasoline.
He went on ahead and had somebody arrange for refueling these tanks from commercial sources.
And he went all the way around to Shreveport and came back, you know, and ended the maneuver prematurely.
And they said, well, you shouldn't have done that.
He said, well, that's war.
You've got to watch.
You have to expect the unexpected.
And he says, I just wanted to prove that what armor can do.
And I was never unhappy because we never caught up with him or not, never to hear about that.
But that was my experience with Patton.
What did you think of him as far as a military leader?
Well...
You take our leaders, which I think are considered to be among our best, would be Patton, and probably our best would be Marshall, and yet MacArthur, of course, Eisenhower.
All of them are different.
Probably the one who has all of the qualities, intelligence, leadership, intellectual.
I already said intelligence, but really
would be Marshall.
You know, if you're looking for the total man.
Each of the others have a little something.
Now Patton, I think he was a, he was a good armored leader.
He loved tanks and gasoline, the smell of it and the grease and all that sort of thing.
He's not a leader in all situations, that's evident, obvious, when he struck that soldier, you know.
Mean like that, he wouldn't accept anything.

Then to, yeah, after hitting him, or before hitting him, yelling about, like, coward, yeller, you ought to get out there, look at those men there, they've been wounded fighting, nothing wrong with you, yeller, coward.
And that's when he struck him.
He was a real scholar.
He studied.
He researched.
He was a good man to have in Europe.
But you couldn't give him all the gasoline like he wanted and just let him go wild.
So you have to be a team player.
But then you have to be tempered with a great MacArthur, for example.
I never really met him or talked to him.
I stood beside him one time.
